definitions: prevent someone from achieving a goal or plan by blocking or hindering their efforts
cause someone to feel upset or annoyed because of inability to change or achieve something
examples: Bad weather frustrated our plans for a beach picnic
Technical problems continued to frustrate the research team's progress
The slow internet connection really frustrates me every day
It frustrates him when people don't listen to his advice

definitions: cook food in hot fat or oil typically in a shallow pan
become extremely hot especially from sun exposure or electrical damage
examples: She likes to fry eggs for breakfast every morning
The chef will fry the fish until golden brown
Your skin will fry if you stay in the sun
The circuit board fried when the power surged yesterday

definitions: engage in sexual intercourse with someone in a crude or casual manner
damage, ruin, or treat someone badly in an aggressive or careless way
express anger, frustration, or emphasis through vulgar exclamation or intensification
examples: They fucked in the back seat of his car
He just wanted to fuck her and leave immediately
The company really fucked over its loyal employees yesterday
Don't fuck with me or you'll regret it later
Fuck, I forgot my wallet at home again today
I don't give a fuck what they think anymore

definitions: avoid making a clear or definite statement or decision about something important
manipulate or adjust facts or figures dishonestly to achieve a desired result
examples: Politicians often fudge their answers during difficult interview questions
She tried to fudge the issue rather than admit mistake
The accountant fudged the numbers to make profits look better
Some students fudge their data to support their hypothesis

definitions: supply or power something with fuel such as gasoline, coal, or other energy source
stimulate or increase the intensity of an emotion, situation, or conflict
examples: We need to fuel the car before the long trip
The power plant fuels the entire city with electricity
His comments only fueled the controversy surrounding the decision
Social media posts fueled speculation about their relationship status

definitions: satisfy or meet requirements, expectations, or conditions that have been set
achieve or realize one's full potential or ambitions in life
carry out a duty, promise, or role as required or expected
examples: The product failed to fulfil our quality standards completely
You must fulfil all criteria to qualify for admission
She finally fulfilled her dream of becoming a doctor
Travel helps many people fulfil their sense of adventure
He fulfilled his promise to help the local community
The president must fulfil many constitutional duties each year

definitions: satisfy or meet requirements, expectations, or conditions that have been set
achieve or realize one's full potential or ambitions in life
carry out a duty, promise, or role as required or expected
examples: The company strives to fulfill all customer orders promptly
Students must fulfill the prerequisites before enrolling in class
She worked hard to fulfill her childhood dream successfully
This job doesn't fulfill me emotionally or intellectually anymore
The mayor promised to fulfill his campaign pledges completely
Parents must fulfill their responsibilities to their children daily

definitions: use hands clumsily or nervously when handling or attempting to do something
search for something awkwardly with hands, especially in darkness or confusion
speak in a nervous or confused way, struggling to find right words
examples: He fumbled with his keys trying to unlock the door
The quarterback fumbled the ball during the crucial play
She fumbled in her purse looking for her phone
I fumbled around in the dark searching for the lightswitch
The speaker fumbled through his presentation without proper preparation
She fumbled for words when asked about her mistake

definitions: emit gas, smoke, or vapor, especially noxious or harmful substances
feel or show great anger or irritation about something
examples: The chemical solution fumed dangerously in the laboratory beaker
Toxic gases fumed from the factory chimney all day
She was fuming about the unfair treatment she received
He fumed silently as his rival took credit again

definitions: work or operate in a proper or normal way
serve a particular purpose or fulfill a specific role in a system
examples: The old computer still functions despite its age today
Her kidneys stopped functioning properly after the accident occurred
The heart functions as a pump for blood circulation
This room functions as both office and guest bedroom

definitions: provide money for a particular purpose, project, or organization through financial support
examples: The government will fund the new research project entirely
Private investors funded her startup company with two million
We need donors to fund our charity programs this year
The scholarship funds education for underprivileged students every semester

definitions: seek and collect money from donors for a charitable cause or organization
examples: The school will fundraise for new playground equipment this fall
She fundraised successfully for cancer research throughout the year
They fundraise through bake sales and charity auctions regularly
The organization fundraises millions annually for disaster relief efforts

definitions: avoid doing something out of fear or reluctance to face difficulty
play or perform funk music with its characteristic rhythmic style
examples: He funked the difficult exam and didn't show up
Don't funk your responsibilities when things get tough here
The band funked all night at the jazz club
They funk with incredible energy and rhythm on stage

definitions: guide or channel something through a narrow space or confined pathway
direct money, resources, or information toward a specific purpose or destination
examples: Wind funneled through the narrow canyon with tremendous force
They funneled the crowd through a single security checkpoint
The company funnels profits into research and development annually
Donors funnel millions through charitable foundations every year worldwide

definitions: grant a temporary leave of absence from work, especially to government or military employees
examples: The company furloughed thousands of workers during the pandemic
The prison furloughed inmates for family emergencies with strict conditions
They will furlough non-essential staff until business improves significantly
The government furloughed federal employees during the budget crisis

definitions: provide a room or building with furniture and fittings
supply or provide someone with something needed or requested
examples: They furnished the apartment with modern Scandinavian style furniture
The landlord furnished all rooms before new tenants arrived
Please furnish all documents required for your visa application
The witness furnished crucial evidence to support the case

definitions: make a long narrow trench in the ground, especially for planting seeds
form wrinkles or lines on the face, especially the forehead from concentration
examples: The farmer furrowed the field before planting corn seeds
Heavy machinery furrowed the soft earth in parallel lines
She furrowed her brow while solving the complex equation
His forehead furrowed with worry about the test results

definitions: help the progress or development of something; promote or advance
go or extend to a greater distance in space or time
examples: This research will further our understanding of climate change
She took courses to further her career in marketing
We decided to further explore the cave system carefully
They furthered their journey into unknown territory yesterday morning

definitions: join or blend things together by melting with intense heat
combine or blend different elements to form a single entity
cause an electrical device to stop working by blowing a fuse
examples: The welder fused the metal pieces together with precision
Heat fused the glass components into one solid piece
The artist fused traditional and modern styles brilliantly together
The companies fused their operations to increase market efficiency
The power surge fused all the lights in the building
Don't overload the circuit or you'll fuse the system

definitions: talk at length in an idle or gossipy way about trivial matters
examples: The neighbors gabbed over the fence for hours yesterday
She loves to gab on the phone with her friends
They gabbed about celebrity gossip during their lunch break
Stop gabbing and get back to work right now

definitions: go from place to place in search of pleasure or entertainment
examples: She likes to gad about town on weekend afternoons
He's always gadding around instead of working on projects
They gadded from party to party all summer long
Stop gadding and settle down to serious work please

definitions: put something in or over someone's mouth to prevent them from speaking
choke or retch as if about to vomit from disgust or physical reaction
examples: The kidnappers gagged their victim with duct tape immediately
They tried to gag the press from reporting the scandal
The awful smell made everyone gag and cover their noses
She gagged on the bitter medicine but swallowed it anyway

definitions: offer something valuable as security for a loan or obligation
measure or estimate something, especially someone's attitude or situation carefully
examples: He gaged his watch to pay for the urgent repairs
The merchant gaged valuable goods against the large loan
It's difficult to gage public opinion on this issue
She tried to gage his reaction before speaking further

definitions: obtain or secure something desired, especially as a result of effort
increase in weight, speed, value, or amount over time
reach or arrive at a destination or desired place
examples: She gained valuable experience working at the startup company
The political party gained more seats in the election
He gained ten pounds during the holiday season unfortunately
The stock gained five percent in value this morning
The hikers finally gained the summit after climbing all day
We gained the shore just before the storm arrived

definitions: make someone feel irritated or resentful through unfair treatment or behavior
make skin sore by continuous rubbing or chafing against something
examples: It galls me when people take credit for others' work
His arrogant attitude really galled everyone at the meeting
The rough saddle galled the horse's back during the ride
These new shoes galled my heels on the long walk

definitions: move at the fastest pace of a horse with all feet leaving ground
proceed or develop at a very fast uncontrolled pace
examples: The horse galloped across the field with amazing speed
The riders galloped toward the finish line in the race
Inflation galloped ahead despite government efforts to control it
The project galloped forward without proper planning or oversight

definitions: play games of chance for money; bet on an uncertain outcome
take risky action hoping for a desired result despite uncertainty
examples: He gambles every weekend at the casino downtown unfortunately
She gambled her savings on lottery tickets last year
The company gambled on launching the product without testing
Don't gamble with your health by ignoring warning signs

definitions: play video games or computer games for entertainment or competition
manipulate a system or situation to gain unfair advantage
examples: He games online with friends every evening after work
Professional players game for hours to improve their skills
Some students try to game the admission system unfairly
Companies game the tax code to minimize their payments

definitions: come together as a group or gang for a common purpose
join together to attack, criticize, or oppose someone unfairly
examples: The workers ganged together to demand better working conditions
Kids often gang up to play team sports together
The bullies ganged up on the new student unfairly
Don't gang up against her just because she disagrees

definitions: undergo tissue death and decay due to lack of blood supply or infection
examples: His foot began to gangrene after the severe frostbite
The wound gangrened because proper treatment was delayed significantly
Without immediate surgery, the infected limb will gangrene rapidly
Diabetes can cause extremities to gangrene if not managed properly

definitions: put someone in prison as punishment for a crime they committed
examples: The judge gaoled him for three years for fraud
They were gaoled without trial during the political upheaval
The authorities gaoled protesters who violated the curfew repeatedly
She was gaoled briefly for refusing to pay the fine

definitions: create or form a gap, space, or opening between things
examples: The earthquake gapped the road making it completely impassable
Years of erosion gapped the cliff face dramatically
The crowd gapped to let the ambulance through quickly
The teeth gapped wider as the child grew older

definitions: stare with one's mouth open wide in amazement or wonder
be or become wide open forming a large opening or gap
examples: The tourists gaped at the magnificent cathedral in awe
Children gaped as the magician performed incredible tricks
The wound gaped open requiring immediate medical attention urgently
A huge chasm gaped before them blocking their path forward

definitions: put or keep a vehicle in a garage for storage or protection
examples: He garages his vintage car during the winter months
We garage both vehicles to protect them from weather
The company garages its fleet of trucks every night
She couldn't garage the RV because it was too tall

definitions: dress someone in distinctive clothes or costume, especially formal or ceremonial
examples: The actors were garbed in elaborate period costumes beautifully
Priests garbed themselves in ceremonial robes for the service
She garbed her daughter in a princess dress for Halloween
The graduates were garbed in traditional caps and gowns

definitions: work in a garden growing and tending plants, flowers, or vegetables
examples: She gardens every weekend during the spring and summer
My grandmother gardened until she was ninety years old
They garden organically without using any chemical pesticides ever
He loves to garden but hates weeding the beds

definitions: decorate with a wreath or festive chain of flowers or leaves
examples: They garlanded the bride with fresh jasmine flowers beautifully
The streets were garlanded for the festival celebration yesterday
Winners were garlanded with laurel wreaths at the ceremony
The statue was garlanded with marigolds during the religious festival

definitions: gather or collect something, especially information, support, or approval gradually
examples: The proposal garnered support from several key board members
Her performance garnered critical acclaim from theater reviewers nationwide
The study garnered data from over ten thousand participants
He garnered enough votes to win the election decisively

definitions: decorate or embellish food with small amounts of food or herbs
legally seize money from someone's wages to pay a debt
examples: The chef garnished each plate with fresh parsley beautifully
She garnished the cocktail with a slice of lime
The court garnished his wages to pay child support
Creditors can garnish your bank account for unpaid debts

definitions: provide a place with troops to defend it from attack or maintain control
examples: The army garrisoned the border town with elite soldiers
They garrisoned the fort to protect the strategic location
Rome garrisoned conquered territories to maintain imperial control effectively
The castle was garrisoned by a hundred skilled warriors

definitions: make a long deep cut or wound in something with a sharp object
examples: He gashed his leg on the barbed wire fence badly
The rocks gashed the boat's hull during the storm
She accidentally gashed her hand while cutting vegetables quickly
The vandals gashed the painting with a knife maliciously

definitions: take a quick sharp breath from surprise, shock, or exertion
struggle to breathe or draw breath with difficulty
examples: The audience gasped when the acrobat nearly fell dramatically
She gasped in horror at the terrible news yesterday
He was gasping for air after running up the stairs
The fish gasped helplessly on the deck of the boat

definitions: control access by means of a gate or barrier system
confine a student to school grounds as a form of punishment
examples: Security gates the community to keep unwanted visitors out
They gate the parking area during special events carefully
The headmaster gated him for breaking the school rules
Students were gated for returning late from town yesterday

definitions: come together or bring people together in one place for a purpose
collect or harvest things from different places into one location
understand or conclude something from available information or evidence
examples: The family gathers every Sunday for dinner together happily
Protesters gathered outside the courthouse demanding justice yesterday
She gathered wildflowers from the meadow this morning carefully
Farmers gather their crops before the frost arrives annually
I gather you're not interested in the job offer
From what I can gather, the meeting went badly

definitions: measure something precisely using an instrument or standard scale
estimate or judge the amount, level, or nature of something carefully
examples: Engineers gauge the pressure in the pipes every hour
The mechanic gauged the tire pressure before the trip
It's hard to gauge public reaction to the new policy
She tried to gauge his mood before asking for help

definitions: look steadily and intently at something for a long time in contemplation
examples: She gazed out the window lost in thought completely
The lovers gazed into each other's eyes romantically
He gazed at the stars wondering about life's mysteries
Tourists gazed in wonder at the ancient ruins silently

definitions: announce or publish something in an official gazette or journal
examples: The government gazetted the new regulations yesterday morning officially
His appointment was gazetted in the official journal promptly
They gazetted the list of award recipients last week
The promotion must be gazetted before it becomes official

definitions: adjust or adapt something to make it suitable for a particular purpose
provide with equipment or clothing appropriate for a particular activity
examples: The course is geared toward beginners learning basic skills
We need to gear our strategy to current market conditions
They geared up for the mountain climbing expedition thoroughly
The store gears cyclists with professional racing equipment daily

definitions: command a horse to go faster or turn to the right
express mild surprise, enthusiasm, or sympathy in informal speech
examples: The farmer geed the horses to move them forward quickly
Gee up, we need to reach town before dark tonight
Gee, I didn't expect to see you here today
Gee whiz, that's an amazing magic trick you performed

definitions: engage enthusiastically or obsessively with a specialized interest, especially technology or pop culture
examples: He geeks out over the latest computer hardware releases
They geeked together about their favorite science fiction shows
She completely geeked when she met her favorite author
We spent hours geeking about comic book characters yesterday
